Title: Arcwise connected part of $\mathbb R^2$
Content:
Here's a question that I share:
 Show that if $D$ is a countable subset of $\mathbb R^2$ (provided with its usual topology) then $X=\mathbb R^2 \backslash D $ is arcwise connected.
AcceptedAnswer: HINT: Not only is $\Bbb R^2\setminus D$ arcwise connected, but you can connect any two points with an arc consisting of at most two straight line segments. Suppose that $p,q\in\Bbb R^2\setminus D$. There are uncountably many straight lines through $p$, and only countably many of those lines intersect $D$, so there are uncountably many straight lines through $p$ that don’t hit $D$. Similarly, there are uncountably many straight lines through $q$ that don’t hit $D$. Can you finish it from here?
